title: Monday, 8th January, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:05 am

Under the terms of the latest cash-and-shares offer to create a UK-based, US-listed entity, Mothercare shareholders would receive 300p a share. This approach on June 1 comprised 230p in cash and 70p-worth of shares in the new holding company, valuing the UK retailer’s equity at about £266m.

BE11:11am

And well done to management for repelling that offer, and also trying quite hard not to tell its shareholders about it.

Fox Directors have also been buying in bulk all the way down from 120p. (I have a small holding). Wondering what to do with it.

Tom Dalgleish Nobody wants to treat pregnancy as anything special anyway
Fox At least any imminent placing seems to have been ruled out for now
red going into the groun as per debs and HoF. they are doomed just dont know it yet.
Forester If you have been in a MTC anytime over the last 5 years you will know why their sales are down 7% and why ultimately the business will cease as we know it.
BE11:14am

Similar to the Debenhams warning last week, it's seen as mostly company specific in the sense that it's quite geared to any reduction in sales and needs to get its promotion strategy right just to keep paddling forward.

#REF! @chad_john a discounting pregnant pause one could say. Sorry
11:14 am
BE11:15am

And, it didn't. Here's Peel Hunt.

BE11:15am

UK Q3 LFL sales fall by 7.2%, (vs PHe -3%), which includes an online sales decline of 6.9% (vs PHe +4.6%). Total UK sales fell by 11%, reflecting store closures. Mothercare was hit by weaker footfall and isn’t a particularly Christmas-orientated stock and has therefore struggled to catch up from a weak start to the quarter. We believe branded pricing is not always consistently priced competitively enough, which remains an issue that has yet to be resolved. The poor sales performance will feed through into weaker gross margins, with Q3 GM likely to be down by 300bps+; we forecast a full-year margin decline of 160bps. Our model now points to a UK loss of £17.9m for the year. Management has cut back on central costs through headcount reductions, which is expected to generate annualised savings of £5m for FY2019.

BE11:15am

Forecast downgrades. Management has guided to an adj PBT range of £1m£5m vs PHe £11.3m (cons £11.8m, range £10m-£14m). We downgrade FY2018 PBT to £0.5m, 0.2p, with FY2019 cut to £5.2m, 2.2p.

Fox Baffling why they rejected the 300p/share offer.
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Net debt c£50m, tough outlook ahead. Taking into account the deterioration in trading, net debt for the year is expected to be in the region of £50m, c1.6x EBITDA, well within the current facilities. However, capital spending is already being curtailed in order to keep debt levels in check, with capex level for the year of c£25m likely to be cut further in 2019E (we forecast £15m), slowing down the store transformation programme. Assuming FY2018 is the nadir, then Mothercare’s balance sheet pressures will recede, although given the very high levels of operational gearing (there’s nothing else to be cut), then any further deterioration in trading will put the business under greater scrutiny from its lenders. The next phase of store closures remain a key part of reducing the cost base of the business.

BE11:16am

"Assuming FY2018 is the nadir" .... why would you do that, tho?

red @fox management looking after themselves i expect
Pharma @Fox, they have been (presumably well) paid for three more years.
chad_john So they have no money to upgrade the stores, headcount is reducing and they can't get their sales strategy right. Sign me up.
doeswalk @rw42 haha oh yeah
chad_john Wonder why Mike Ashley hasn't bought any.
BE11:17am

Mothercare's recent history is mostly nadirs. Numis incoming.

Fox To be fair the directors have been buying all the way down. Misjudgement?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

Although there are welcome signs of stabilisation
in the International division, the acute operational gearing in the domestic business causes its FY18 PBT expectations to fall further to a range of between £1m and £5m (Numis previous estimate £10m). The year-end debt position is within existing group covenants. Our Recommendation/ Target Price have been under review since the interims. We update with a Hold rating, believing that uncertainty over trading trends and financing could for the time being over-ride considerations of the group's strategic value and recovery potential.

hornblower MTC has £12.5m debt maturity in November this year - where is that coming from?
chad_john @Fox or a smokescreen.
BE11:18am

And Canaccord, which I think is one of the few sellers out there.

BE11:19am

Management now expects y/e net debt of c. £50m vs. CGe £34m and stated that there is still 'sufficient' liquidity and covenant headroom at this level. We assume a £5m working capital outflow (partly timing), £27m cash cost for exceptionals and pension and £25m capex. We assume that capex falls from £25m in FY18E to £15m in FY19E.
While the benefits of central cost reduction should start to come through in FY19E, should there be no improvement in trading, then we think further action would be required in the run-up to peak trading 2018 to secure liquidity.

red @fox u make the mistake that all directors are smart people. most folks are thick it appears these days.
11:20 am
BE11:20am

We think that there is a place for Mothercare in the UK, but the right-sizing of the store portfolio needs to happen faster. International is profitable and could well return to long-term growth. From an equity investment perspective though, the high operational gearing of the UK business makes the risk:reward ratio highly unfavourable, particularly given the weak balance sheet.
Along with y/e net debt of c. £50m the company has an actuarial pension deficit of £139m (2017 tri-annual valuation). The rent bill was £42.8m in FY17 with total operating lease commitments of £235m (average lease length 4.5 years). So, before attributing any value to the assets of the business, the cost of the liabilities is potentially over £400m.
This makes Mothercare a difficult take-out candidate, despite the potential strategic
value of the business. The reality is, in our view, that the UK business would already have
gone through administration (and potentially come out a stronger, right-sized business)
were it not for the cash flows of International keeping it afloat. We cut our DCF based price target from 47p to 29p, reflecting our earnings cuts as well as lower capex assumptions and a roll-forward. Maintain SELL.

Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous and assorted people
BE11:21am

Sector wise, no particular response for the reasons mentioned above.

BE11:23am

Let me grab Peel Hunt to a view of the week.

BE11:23am

What we have learned so far. Updates from Next and John Lewis set a positive tone, which was more a function of excessively downbeat expectations in the press, rather than particularly stellar numbers. Both confirmed that the consumer was out to spend, although the product and pricing had to be competitive. The Debenhams’ profit warning was the most predicted slip-up, which serves to highlight the structural differences across the sector – while our structural growth picks have fully mitigated FX pressures, largely grown gross margins, and will hopefully post double-digit revenue growth over peak, the structurally challenged retailers such as Debenhams are facing up to declining gross margins and inflation rates that are exceeding revenue growth.

wayneJ Just looking - Argos has rather a large selection of cots etc. The issue for Mothercare is how unique / exclusive is their range?
FATDAZ I think we came to a similar conclusion for HMV too
11:23 am
BE11:24am

Big week for the top picks. We are expecting trading updates from 12 retailers in our universe next week, including a number of our top picks. We are expecting strong statements from Joules#, SuperGroup, boohoo, B&M Bargains and Quiz (all BUYs apart from Quiz, which is not yet under coverage); all offer a good chance of upgrades. While Topps# is not the Christmas shop of choice, we look for signs that the strong start to the year has continued across Q1 against our modest forecast expectations. Elsewhere, we suspect Ted may have found the going tougher, as has M&S, but look for forecasts here to be maintained. Following November’s profit warning, Mothercare’s update is unlikely to make pretty reading, but having already halved forecasts, this should be baked into market expectations.

Hamster on a Piano CLLN frying shorts today, can't imagine any revised business plan being good for shareholders

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: T118 revenues of $1,235m were in line (cons. $1,233m), while an underlying
adjusted EBITDA of $530m/42.9%% was 5% ahead. Core MCRO sales fell 2.7% to
$665m (H217: -2.7%) with SUSE +13.1% to $164m and the rest -7.0% to $501m.
Core EBITDA of $303m/45.6% saw margins fall 70bp y/y as operational efficiencies
were delayed pending low-end of the target with poor sales execution in the Americas
noted, while it delivered an EBITDA of $227m/39.8% (Q4 16: 33.7%). This is after a
$25m deferred income haircut we note. Bad debt provisions also increased.

BE11:31am

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: SUSE bookings fell 2% (H217: +5%) with US sales leadership replaced and mgt
acknowledging a shift to the cloud weighing. ACV grew just 2.5% y/y (H217: +15%).

11:31 am
BE11:31am

(@ROTR: G4S is on the back of a UBS upgrade, and I think also a Redburn upgrade at the end of last week.)

BE11:32am

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: Having indicated it expected c10%pa EBITDA growth in each year from 1 Nov. 17
onwards, mgt today indicated it is targeting 15-20%pa total returns. Base EBITDA is
$1,401m so cons. for the balance of FY18 of $1,606m represents 15% growth on this.
Mgt is now targeting 25% tax rate from 33% previously (UBSe: 28%).

BE11:32am

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: The announcement of Chris Kennedy (ex-ARM) as CFO as Mike Phillips moves to Head of M&A is a surprise.

UBS pushing as part of a sector thing, all about computers and junk.

BE11:47am

We expect Support Services to see accelerating structural change in 2018 as digitalisation impacts
the B2B world. This can create new structural growth (e.g. Security, Testing), create opportunities for productivity gains (Facilities Management), or bring new competitive threats (Staffing, Distribution). At the same time, market momentum is shifting and we have a preference for late- cycle defensives vs. early-cycle plays. Cash deployment should accelerate again in 2018, which may see consolidation benefits (e.g. Security, Distribution) or raise competitive threats (Rental).

BE11:49am

It's a very long note and it doesn't seem to break out the individual company calls in among the sector stuff, so here's the sector stuff.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

We believe security markets are currently benefiting from a late-cycle economic pick-up, extra work from security concerns across Developed Markets, and structural improvement as technology becomes a bigger part of guarding contracts. However, the late cycle also comes at the expense of very high staff turnover which holds back margin progress. The cash handling industry is going through its own shift as declining cash usage is met with increasing outsourcing penetration for new solutions.

gh I wonder whether it is just me who see Henry Boot at 239p
BE11:50am

We are Buy rated on G4S as we see growth accelerating and portfolio optionality for the company's cash unit. Our Neutral rating on Securitas reflects the full valuation and concerns around the very high US staff turnover.

SOCO International plc ("SOCO") notes the recent press speculation regarding a possible transaction with Kuwait Energy plc ("Kuwait Energy"). SOCO confirms that, in the context of its stated objective to strategically reshape its business and grow its portfolio, it is evaluating a potential merger of equals with Kuwait Energy.

Discussions with Kuwait Energy's newly-constituted Board of Directors are preliminary and no transaction terms have been agreed.
